comments.author: Cedar
comments.content: That looks really amazing, and right up my alley!  I am saving this recipe, and plan on trying it later this week!

comments.author: Tai
comments.content: I used to make this all the time in college to save money. But I had no idea it was an actual, legitimate, named dish. I forgot how much I liked it.

comments.author: fanny
comments.content:
Hmmmm it looks utterly delicious Michael.
xxx

comments.author: Gayla
comments.content: This looks yummy.  I am going to have to make this ... I need to dig up Heidi's instructions on making greek yogurt since its not widely available here.  Thanks for sharing this!

comments.author: Anh
comments.content: This is an amazing post! So delicious!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks everyone! If you make it, please comment again and let us know how it turned out.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: See also this soup recipe for a way to use up the leftovers.

comments.author: Jirair Khatcheressian
comments.content: I have tried to find the recipie that my Aunt uses, but could not find it anywhere. I swear she makes the best Mujaddara. Here is the secret. Cook plenty of onions in olive oil until deep brown color, (you don't want to burn the onion), then add enough water to cook the rice and lentil with) and boil the water. This becomes your broth. DO cook the lentils separately first, but not all the way, and then combine the rice, semi cooked lentils with enough of this prepared "onion broth", as if cooking pilaf. Of course add salt and pepper to taste. I top the musaddara with Laban.

comments.author: molahs4
comments.content:
I've made this in the past, but using your recipe as a guideline it was the best ever. Cooking the rice and lentils separately made it easier to use the right ratio (I'm bad at judging how much dry beans/lentils will turn into when cooked). I mixed the caramelized onions in with the rice/lentils to make it more kid friendly, and removed the cinnamon completely. I served mine with prepared tahini (mixed with cumin, lemon juice, water, salt, za'atar) and steamed beets with their greens. Mmmmmmm.

Too bad the leftovers got eaten too- now I can't make the soup.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Glad it worked out well. The tahini sauce is popular at our house as well!

comments.author: shelly
comments.content: Thanks for posting this recipe. I had mujadara at a middle-eastern restaurant and wanted to try making it myself. Your version is easy and delicious! I can't wait to try more of your recipes.

comments.author: Alyson
comments.content: Thank you for a delicious recipe.  I found your blog after deciding to try to cut meat out of my diet.  With recipes like yours, so far, it has been easy to eat vegetarian!  I put in about a tablespoon each of cinnamon and cumin for stronger flavor.  It was so good - I've actually made it twice in a week, and served it to non-vegetarian friends who asked for second helpings.

comments.author: er
comments.content: Thanks so much for this yummy recipe. Good friends gathered and had a Middle Eastern themed potluck. It was my first try to cook a Middle Eastern dish. I want to explore more!

comments.author: Joy
comments.content: This dish has saved my vegan butt at several church potlucks.  No one enjoys a cranky, sugar crashed priest--and everyone loves the dish!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: HI Joy - I'm so glad you like it, thanks for letting me know. It is handy to have a repertoire of good potluck dishes isn't it? Here is another one you might like: https://herbivoracious.com/2008/08/how-to-make-a-d.html

comments.author: Lali
comments.content: I noticed the very exact same recipe on Sparkpeople, word for word, including (see "carmalized onions" in Joy of Cooking...) wondering. I loved it regardless who should get the credit for the dish!!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Could you send me the link? It is my original recipe, someone is apparently
stealing my content (which is common, unfortunately). Thanks for letting me
know.


I noticed the very exact same recipe on Sparkpeople, word for word,

comments.author: Surik Celibataire
comments.content: Mmmmm...this sounds like a delicious dish an it looks awesome. Thanks for the recipe. I think i'll add some chilli to spice it a bit.

comments.author: Eric
comments.content:
This is a great recipe! I love mujadara, and this recipe is very close to what I get at a local Middle Eastern restaurant.

I found that I had to really hit the cumin and cinnamon hard: I probably put 1.5 tsp each. Also, if you have time to caramelize the onions, do it! This really makes the dish. The second time I made it, I didn't feel like baby sitting onions for an hour or two, so I just browned them. Still very good.

comments.author: Alan and Ann Alaia Woods
comments.content:
found your recipe searching for a Mujadara that wouldn't be as oily as a packaged an Israeli friend gave us.  Yours worked wonderfully -- we made a minor modification, as vegans, deleting the butter, and not including yoghurt.  Delicious results --and having found the soup variation, will try that next!

Thanks--

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks Alan and Ann! I'm glad you liked it and I appreciate you letting me know.

comments.author: Ashley R.
comments.content: I just made this and it was fantastic! I had to add a bit more cumin for my taste and used coriander in place of the cinnamon! YUM! I have enough to feed a small army though!

comments.author: Kathleen
comments.content: has anyone tried this with canned lentils, already cooked?

comments.author: Zack B
comments.content: I have to disagree on the slow caramelization of the onions.  Cooking them over a higher heat gives you a caramelized exterior and a contrasting pungent inside that I like better.  Also I agree with the cinnamon & cumin suggestion.

comments.author: Rachel
comments.content: Just now found this site through stumbleupon.  This recipe is DEFINITELY up my alley! I think tomorrow I'll get the ingredients and cook this - I'd love for my boyfriend to try it, too. I hope to get him hooked on some crazy delicious vegan meals :)

comments.author: Rachel
comments.content:
I agree about the onions - they really do this! Btw, (in response to Kathleen's question) I did use a can of precooked lentils, and it did taste great.
Om nom

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN">
@Rachel - I'm glad you liked it, and thanks for the update on the lentils and onions!

comments.author: Arathi
comments.content:
Hi Michael,

I recently stumbled upon your website,(I was actually looking for a mujadara recipe, and I landed right here!)..I tried your recipe today, and it turned out wonderful!My husband and I simply loved it...The light cinnamon flavor was such a nice touch..I will definitely be trying more from your blog! Keep up the good work!

comments.author: Elisabeth
comments.content: I made this tonight for my parents, and it was a success. As a vegan your blog is just what I've been looking for(asian food!). I was so happy when I found there was vegetarian and even vegan recipes. The chana masala was delicious, and I can't wait to try out the urad dal patties.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Elisabeth - I'm so glad you liked those dishes! Thanks for emailing to let me know, that makes my day.

comments.author: Karen
comments.content: I must say I was skeptical about the cumin and particularly the cinnamon.  I decided to season a small portion rather than 'ruin' the whole dish.  The two spices make the dish!  Especially the cinnamon!  Loved it.  I used just the 1/4t of each and what a difference.  I served it with a wedge of lemon on the side to squeeze on top.  Too bad my husband is not a fan of this dish.  We will have it again, but not too often for my husband's sake.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @Karen - That was really smart of you to try a test sample with the spices to see if you liked it that way... and I'm glad you did like it!

comments.author: Jay
comments.content: This recipe lists butter as one of the ingredients. Butter isn't vegan. You might want to change your description to simply "vegetarian and gluten free".

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Good catch, Jay. I've updated it to say "vegan (if you use oil or margarine instead of butter)".  (My vegan and gluten-free notes are always "assuming you make obvious substitutions", but sometimes I forget to note the details for readers).

Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: Aparna
comments.content: Had bookmarked this sometime back and made it with a few changes. Was very good. Thanks. My post is at http://www.mydiversekitchen.com/2010/06/cucumber-pachadi-cucumber-in-spiced.html

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Aparna - I like your Indian twist on the mujadara, that sounds delicious!

comments.author: ed hardy
comments.content: You might want to change your description to simply "vegetarian and gluten free".

comments.author: rony
comments.content: loll

comments.author: Rachelle
comments.content:
Great recipe! I love Lebanese staples like hummus, tabbouleh, falafel, tzaziki, etc. and I'm thrilled to branch out a bit. Like other commenters, I added more more cumin and cinnamon. And more caramelized onions.

I'm curious about your suggestion not to use French lentils. That's what I used and it turned out great. Are you talking about the dark brown Puy lentils? They hold their shape really well . . .

comments.author: Mahmoud Mirza
comments.content: this is my favorite  arabic dish! it look realllyyyyy goooddd ! :)

comments.author: andrea
comments.content: I have a hard time believing I need all of these onions! but, I am using the wait for them to cook as a meditation....can't wait! Your recipe (and the photo) look most like the dish I grew to love in DC...have had lots of poor imitations---so I can't wait! (40 more minutes!)

comments.author: andrea
comments.content: I'm not the cook, but I tried this once with French lentils and while it was good, it is much, much better with the brown lentils...French lentils have a different taste and texture, and don't taste like mujardara is supposed to taste...imho.

comments.author: Carrie Ann
comments.content: Delicious! Served with a bit of greek yogurt. Planning on having this for lunch all week. Thanks for sharing!

comments.author: Barbara
comments.content: Love this dish and your version is excellent..Have made it many times and making it tonight...Thanks

comments.author: Linda
comments.content: Hi Michael! My husband brought home a carry out of this dish from a lebanese place and I fell in love! He said he could make it and I was so doubtful..but he found your recipe and gave it a try and Boy! It was almost as good as that take out and cost tremendously less to make at home. Excellent recipe that we will make again and again! Thanks for sharing. I will never be a doubter again! And he can keep trying new recipes on me!:) He is making a second batch since he saw he could do it!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Nice :) It makes me happy to hear that you have mastered it at home.

comments.author: Lehua PIschke
comments.content: I'm making it for a second time--for my German, Irish, Scottish, Filipino, Chinese son to take for lunch!  He loves it!  Found your recipe searching for lentil recipes.  I used Le Puy instead of brown lentils, but since I'd never had it before, I didn't know the difference. . .I'll have to try it another time with what you actually SPECIFY.  Thanks for such a simple dish!  It'll be good for my daughter's vegetarian roommate, too (and my daughter!).

comments.author: whoyouthink
comments.content: looks awesome, would be amazing with some fancy mushrooms thrown in at the second stage of the onion carmelization.

comments.author: Wendy M.
comments.content: Worked great for me! I drained and rinced my canned lentils before adding it to the cooked rice. Delicious dish!  I think this will be my newest favourite rice dish!

comments.author: Wendy M.
comments.content: This rice dish is amazing!  I followed recipe to the letter except I used a large can of brown lentils that I drained and rinced and found it absolutely delicious.  I will be making this again and again!

comments.author: rweb
comments.content: Thanks - this dish was amazing!  We loved the combination of flavors, and the ratio of rice to lentils was really nice.  This one is definitely going in my recipe book.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Good deal! Isn't it nice to find pleasure in such simple ingredients?


Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
p.s. I like your resource tweets; try to do an occasional one that is just a thought without a link, and maybe mix in the occasional vaguely personal one. otherwise your stream reads like a pure business "push account" which people don't really get excited about. just be you - you don't have to tweet constantly, even 3 times a week will help.




Michael Natkin

comments.author: Jamie
comments.content: This was yummy. I used 1.5 tsps of cinnamon and cumin. This recipe makes a lot more than 4 servings though!

comments.author: Marina
comments.content: Made this today, and it was just great-great dinner. I did adjust some of the ingredients: 1.Used black "Beluga" lentils. 2. Didn't have white wine or vermouth, so used combination of red wine 1/3 cup and half of the orange. 3. Used 1/2 teaspoon cumin to 1/4 cinnamon. Was a little intimidated to use cinnamon, but it came out just perfect. Thanks for the recipe, it was very easy to follow. I posted picture of what I made.

comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: Looks delicious but unfortunately, mine tastes more like carmelized onion rice pudding! 1/4 tsp cinnamon is WAYYY too much cinnamon! Try a few dashes instead, please!

comments.author: Natalie
comments.content:
I just found this recipe and adapted it to a baked version for dinner tonight.  It was wonderful!  Thank you so much.  

Here is a link to how I baked it, if you are interested:

http://myfoodfiles.blogspot.com/2012/04/baked-mujadarah.html

comments.author: Alice
comments.content:
This recipe has been a staple in my repetoire since I found it here a few years ago.  Though I have to comment regarding the responses about the quantities it makes/ serves.  We use it as the main dish for two - me and hubbie - and usually only have enough left for two small lunch servings!
Absolutely delicious, even when you forget the spices!  I probably shouldn't try to cook things from memory... but the onions and the yoghurt keep it tasty.  Thanks Michael!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I'm so glad you like it, and thanks for the comment about the serving size!!

comments.author: Sheri
comments.content:
Hello Michael,

I listened to you today on WPR, and am so glad I did!  Iove your blog and all of the recipes look amazing.  Tried this one tonight and it is to die for!  Really fantastic...  I have never carmalized onions before, and it was definately worth the time.  So yummy!

I look forward to trying many more recipes.  And your book is on the top of my b-day wish list.  : )

Sheri

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Oh good, glad to have a new reader, and delighted to hear you enjoyed the mujadara. Now that you've got the method for caramelizing onions, you can use them for everything from sandwiches to pastas.

comments.author: laurel
comments.content: The recipe looked great.  It smelled fantastic as it cooked.  I made sure to not overcook the rice and lentils (separately).  I was disappointed with the outcome, but will definitely try again with more spices and perhaps some raisins and toasted almond slivers.  It was bland for our taste and it has so much promise.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Laurel - I appreciate the feedback. Mujadara is not meant to be a brightly flavored dish. It is more subtle, mainly just about the balance between the earthy lentils, comforting rice, and sweet/savory onions. As long as you really thoroughly caramelized the onions and used the full amount of them, you made it right so it just might not be a dish that you enjoy.

comments.author: Lowen Gartner
comments.content:
Fantastic dish.   

1) Authentic is not caramelized onions, but faster cooked charred onions.  I like to do a combination. (I was raised in Lebanon)

2) Instead of the cinnamon/cumin as suggested, look for Lebanese 7-spice blend or Baharet spice (essentially the same) from North Africa.

3) substitute quinoa for rice.

Cheers - thanks for this post.

comments.author: Leanna
comments.content:
I tried this tonight, with a few modifications! It was really good, thanks for the idea!

Check out my additions below...I added mushrooms, kale, and raisins and it turned out pretty good :)
http://freetoeatandbe.blogspot.com/2012/08/mushroom-and-raisin-mujadara.html

comments.author: Heather
comments.content: You MUST eat this with Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce!

comments.author: Diego
comments.content: Just made this with the zucchini fritters and a simple roasted cauliflower. I doubled the spices and cooked the lentils and rice together (added the lentils in the last 25 minutes). I liked it quite a bit, but there was still something missing for me.

comments.author: Kristen
comments.content: I just made this-- delicious! I think I overcooked the lentils, but it still tastes okay. I added some sliced manzanilla olives and a can of garbanzo beans and the olives add a nice little kick.

comments.author: Jbird
comments.content: are the amounts for lentils and rice the dry amounts or is that how much cooked lentils/rice i should use? can't wait to make this!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Those are the dry amounts.

comments.author: Rom
comments.content: You can also substitute split mung beans (with skins removed, available in all Indian grocery stores) for lentils for variety and different taste.  It is still very nutritious and healthy.

comments.author: Koussa
comments.content:
Thank you for this excellent recipe; however, it would be nice to aknowledge that this is a Lebanese dish or at least a Mediterranean dish and in this type of cuisine we hardly use butter.
You could sudstitute  rice with cracked wheat (bulgur) and serve this dish with a cabbage salad ( tomatoes, thinly sliced cabbage, lemon juice and olive oil).

comments.author: jbird
comments.content: Thanks for getting back to me so quickly with that clarification, I made this in February and it was delicious, especially with a bit of garlic chili paste added for some heat.  I'm making it again for a party next week, any suggestions for side dishes that would compliment this? (you had mentioned cucumber salad) Thank you for this tasty, easy, low cost recipe!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: You bet! Mujadara is a great start on a Middle Eastern meal, so you could have some subset of hummus, baba ghanouj, the cucumber soup from my cookbook, harissa potatoes: https://herbivoracious.com/2012/10/harissa-potatoes-recipe.html, marinated feta: https://herbivoracious.com/2012/01/quick-marinated-feta-recipe.html, lentil soup: https://herbivoracious.com/2008/04/recipe-syrian-y.html etc.

comments.author: nick
comments.content: Just finished with recipe, can't wait for the onions to camelize.  Thx Michael for your recipe.  My lentils are about 25 ys.old but cooked up just fine haha.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I've found a few bags of lentils like that over the years :)

comments.author: Bill
comments.content: love it.  we always has this dish on Fridays during Lent...My mother used clarified butter (no oil) and no cumin, but Lebanese 7 spices instead. Always served it with Cucumber/Laban/garlic (yogurt) cold salad and hot baked Pita bread. Sooooooooooo  good.  Left overs reheated is great also.

comments.author: Myong
comments.content: I made this dish today, it's absolutely delicious!!  I used thinly sliced scallions on top instead of parsley.   Thank you for posting this recipe!  I can't wait to try your other recipes.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I like it that way too!
